Motherâ€™s Day can be fraught for many reasons for many people. There are blended, foster and grandparent-led families and homes where other loving people have stepped into mothering roles who often go unacknowledged. And there are plenty of families out there like the Loduca-Smiths â€“ between 2 million and 3.7 million children under age 18 have an LGBTQ parent, and approximately 200,000 of them are being raised by a same-sex couple.
But some circumstances can be particularly difficult. Kids, or their mothers, may be grieving a death, or separated because of illness, addiction , or incarceration. For kids, parents, and caregivers who are bombarded by messages of â€œtraditionalâ€ motherhood and Motherâ€™s Day activities at school, corporate daycare, and at church, it can be particularly isolating.

One story is about a black, lesbian couple with an adorable daughter, who are all thriving despite the judgments of others. Another is about an Army veteran and entrepreneur who is raising her fifteen-year-old half-sister. â€œOur mother has come in and out of both our lives,â€ she says. â€œAnd if youâ€™ve gone through something thatâ€™s not great, you donâ€™t want it to happen to other people.â€
